FEATURED NEWS

Justia Live Blogging from Google's I/O Conference

Google hosted its annual I/O developer conference at Shoreline Amphitheatre, just down the road from Justia’s headquarters in Mountain View. The conference typically covers all of the new products and developments that Google will be launching in the near future, and this year was no different. Nick, one of our engineers, attended the conference, as he has done since it began in 2007, and live blogged about it this year. In his series of posts, Nick discusses Google’s announcements on a number of topics, including AMP, HTTPS, structured data, and more.

TIP OF THE MONTH

Complete Your Justia Lawyer Directory Profile

Our data analysis shows lawyers with complete profiles in Justia’s Lawyer Directory receive 76 times more client contacts than those with incomplete profiles. To make your profile more complete, we suggest adding a professional photo and short biography, participating in Ask a Lawyer, and connecting your profile to your social media accounts. If you need help accessing your profile, contact us!

Tech News

Google to Launch a Jobs Search Engine in the U.S.

At its recent I/O developer conference, Google announced that it will be expanding into the jobs search arena, at least for jobs in the United States. As it rolls out this new service, the search engine will begin to identify queries that look like job searches, and in its results it will highlight jobs the user may be interested in. Google mentioned that it will be partnering with other job search engines, such as LinkedIn, Facebook, and Glassdoor, rather than seeking to displace them.

Two Major Changes Potentially Coming to EU’s Right to Be Forgotten With Global Implications

Google’s Senior Privacy Counsel Peter Fleischer discusses two major issues presented by the EU’s consideration of a “right to be forgotten” (RTBF). Specifically, Fleischer considers (1) whether RTBF should be absolute — requiring automatic delisting — when the underlying content in dispute involves “sensitive personal data” and (2) whether RTBF should be enforced in places outside of the EU’s jurisdiction. Fleischer cautions against policies that place the interests of individuals over the broader public interest.

Google Assistant Comes to iPhone, Adds Alerts, Hands-Free Calling & More

Another announcement Google made at its I/O developer conference was that it will be making its voice-activated Assistant available for iPhone users, to compete with Apple’s Siri and Microsoft’s Cortana. Assistant will also be getting some new features, including notifications and reminders, type or voice input, hands-free calling, and more.

EU Fines Facebook $122 Million For Misleading Information Over WhatsApp Buyout

The European Union fined Facebook 110 million euros ($122 million) for providing misleading information related to its buyout of the mobile messaging service WhatsApp. The European Commission stated that the amount of the fine is proportionate and hopes that it serves as a deterrent to other companies that consider providing inaccurate or incomplete information in advance of a merger.

‘Google’ Not Generic, Appeals Court Rules In Trademark Case

The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit recently held that although “Google” is often used as a verb, it is not synonymous with “searching the web” and thus is not “generic” for the purposes of trademark law. The court found that the plaintiffs failed to prove that people use the word “google” to mean generic web searches rather than going to Google to conduct a search. Thus, Google has the right to protect its trademark.

FCC Votes to Begin Rollback of Net Neutrality Regulations

In a 2-1 vote along party lines, the FCC commissioners took the first steps toward loosening the regulations on cable and telecom companies, often known as net neutrality rules. Under the Obama administration, the FCC required that internet service providers such as Comcast or Verizon treat all web traffic equally and fairly, which meant that they could not discriminate among content providers by blocking access or throttling speed.

Google Unveils Next Generation Products at Google I/O Event

Also announced at Google’s I/O development conference were a few next-generation products we can expect the search engine giant to unveil over the next several months: Lens, which allows users to get relevant information about a place or object by uploading a photo of it; Google Assistant on iPhone (the voice-activated assistant was already available on Android devices); an expanded smart reply system for email, new photo tools, and more.

SEO News

Google Analytics to Unify Users Across AMP and Non-AMP Pages

Google will soon be unifying users of AMP and non-AMP versions of pages for which Analytics data is being collected. This means that AMP pages will be getting more support from this service as it identifies sets of distinct user IDs that are actually the same user simply accessing the AMP and non-AMP versions of these pages. These views are no longer being counted as more than one session, meaning that measurements such as time spent on a site are expected to rise on a one-time basis until the unification process is complete.

Google Announces Google Lens, An AI-Powered Visual Search Tool

At its recent I/O conference, Google introduced a new visual search tool called Google Lens. This new machine learning and AI-based product will initially be available in Google Assistant and Google Photos. It will be able to understand what users are viewing and offer them background information and options for additional action, such as to purchase products identified in photos.

Google Rolls Out New Event Search Feature On App & Mobile Web

The Google app and mobile web version now make it easier to search for events. Users can enter queries such as “rock concerts this weekend” and see listings of activities from multiple websites. There are also options to click through and purchase tickets or get more details about events listed in the search results.

Google Advertisers Can Now See Historical Quality Score Data in AdWords

Google has made seven historical quality score data metrics available in AdWords. These new reporting columns are easily visible, and allow advertisers to access data for items including landing page experience and ad relevance. The data for certain quality scores will be segmented by day, assuming there is enough data to report for a given date, making it possible to determine how those scores have changed over time.

How Google Measures the Authority of Web Pages

While Google does not rely on any single factor in ranking individual pages, it appears to consistently use a core group of metrics in determining how authoritative a page is. While content and linking are still considered to be two of the most important factors, a number of other metrics, thought to be derived in large part from the work of Google’s quality raters, have a significant impact. And while sitewide ranking signals make a difference, authority is typically measured on a page-by-page basis.

Social Media News

Facebook Must Remove Hate Speech Posts, Austrian Court Rules

Following what seems to be an increasing trend among European governments, an Austrian court has ruled that Facebook must remove content deemed to be hate speech regarding a specific individual from its platforms on a global basis. This ruling comes after German lawmakers agreed to back measures that would impose steep fines on social media companies for failing to promptly remove hate speech and other offensive content, an approach that politicians in the UK have signaled they may follow. Facebook has been under increasing pressure to police content across multiple jurisdictions in light of reports that fake news outlets have utilized the service to influence election outcomes, as well as multiple disturbing incidents that have been broadcast via Facebook Live.

Instagram Copies Snapchat Again, This Time With Fun Face Masks

Facebook-owned photo-sharing app Instagram has added a feature already well-known to SnapChat users: the ability to add digital embellishments like animal ears to selfies. Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s Chief Executive Officer, believes that face filters and other camera tools will be a big step toward augmented reality tech innovations and developments over the coming year.

Facebook Updates News Feed to Combat ‘Low Quality’ Websites

Facebook’s latest News Feed algorithm update is focused on limiting the reach of links to ad-heavy websites that are deemed to have minimal substantive content. This update will also block ads displayed on these websites, the ultimate result of which will make it far more difficult for domain owners whose websites display disruptive ads and little quality content to draw significant traffic from Facebook.

Twitter Adds Advanced Privacy Controls, New Data Collection Methods

A new set of advanced privacy controls on Twitter aims to provide insight about how the social media platform uses your data, and also offers more control to users over this information. Particularly relevant for those whose websites use embedded tweets, these new privacy controls also allow users more oversight of their Twitter data profile, among other personal data.

Legal Industry News

How to Make Better Technology Choices For Your Practice

Much like the requisite tools of any professional trade, choosing the right software programs for a law practice can go a long way toward ensuring its success. The right software can help a legal team work more quickly, get paid sooner, stay on top of deadlines, and do better work on the whole. The sticker price is only one small factor in the decision-making process, however. There are additional considerations and questions to keep in mind to ensure the software you choose is best suited to the needs of your firm.

Six Simple Ways to Increase Legal Document Security

Over the past decade, technology has been gradually evolving to the legal realm; digital document organization and dissemination are now integrated into daily life at many law firms. Electronic signatures and other digital advancements come with their own set of security concerns, however. From properly maintaining backup files to ensuring compliance with federal e-sign laws, the ins and outs of these technological aids are worth learning for the benefit of your law practice.

ABA Expresses Concern About Border Searches of Lawyer Laptops and Other Electronic Devices

President of the American Bar Association, Linda Klein, recently expressed concern about the practices associated with border searches that allow lawyers’ laptops and other electronic devices to be searched. Klein’s May 5 letter to the Department of Homeland Security requests that policies and procedures be established to ensure the confidentiality of data an attorney might have on their devices that qualifies as privileged material associated with their clients.

Chelsea Manning Walks Back Into a World She Helped Transform

After serving seven years in military prison for leaking classified documents to WikiLeaks, former U.S. Army private Chelsea Manning was released on May 17. Her actions inspired subsequent acts of whistleblowing, the size and rate of which seem to have accelerated in the past handful of years since her conviction. Many believe that Manning both influenced a new era of whistleblowing and helped changed the way that journalism and the government function.
